author: peterbisma
title: African Journalists - AJEOT 2022
description: How do we build competent journalists in sub-saharan Africa to influence policy debate and set the right tone for blockchain discourse and policy adoption?

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal consists of two parts: 1. journalism training and 2. the future outcome of “influencing policy.” Both are outside this Challenge’s scope, which is why this section gets one star.
      ...      
To clarify, the Challenge aims for legal & financial solutions that can specifically help proposers. Due to this apparent conflict, the value-added to the Cardano ecosystem is too far into the future to measure impact.
      ...      
To aid the proposer, it seems helpful to mention that as it is written, this proposal currently meets the goals of these two Fund9 Challenges: 1. Challenge & Scouted for Students 2. Grow Africa, Grow Cardano. If not funded, consider rewriting to meet the Legal & Financial Implementations Challenge setting, or switch to one of the two Challenges mentioned if they are still available.
      ...      
The key metrics aim at the number of journalists trained. The future “policy influence” is not mentioned in the key metrics. If this proposal is rewritten, consider a more short-term benefit directed at proposers and/or funded Catalyst teams.
      ...      
The proposal does not address scaling and future sustainability. Though scaling is unnecessary to consider for this proposal, future sustainability could be planned for in terms of the future needs of the journalists in influencing policy in their future work.
f6_assessments.q1:
There is adequate evidence of relevant skills and experience needed to implement the proposal. That said, there are only two names attached to the proposal. At the same time, the mention of a team comprised of “researchers, think tank management, economists, Media Personnel, policy experts, and blockchain enthusiasts with over 20 years of experience in public policy” seems to pose a discrepancy for voters.
...
The outlined budget is clear for the training aspect, though there is room for a more detailed cost breakdown (i.e. details of $7K needed for “Participant Traveling Grant”). The budget seems reasonable for prices in this area of the world. The authors include no plans for additional funds.
...
The proposal does not offer a realistic timetable for completing the work. There is a timetable for the coursework, but none to accomplish “influencing policy.” However, it seems too tricky an item to define a timeline for––another reason for rewriting.
...
The proposal explains only some of the technical aspects of implementation relating to the initial journalist training but not the entire solution. As a working professional in a related field, this assessor determines that there is a sound plan for training the journalist students, and a competent institution has been selected. “Influencing policy” seems difficult to plan for and will probably leave voters looking for a more measurable solution.
...
In terms of risks, it brings up only one concern which appears to be solved in the budget under the “Participant Traveling Grant,” though further details would help voters determine that for themselves. No other potential risks are stated, though it seems there should be many to consider.
f6_assessments.q2:
There is no roadmap with milestones and a clear time horizon for achievement for voters to consider. The metrics only define one part of the success of the proposal. If rewritten to only consider the outcome of “trained journalists,” these metrics would suffice (though it would be even further outside of solving this specific Challenge’s problem statement).
...
The target problem is not able to be measured by current metrics. The solution does not address the problem in full, as stated above. No accessible public channel for delivering regular updates to the community for auditing progress is given.
...
This is why this section is being given 1 star.
f6_assessments.reply: The assessor fails to consider the proposal's description as to how it fits the challenge. Legal and Financial services should be viewed holistically to include existing laws that curtail funded proposals from functioning. In such a situation, journalists would be critical to protecting the interest of the community in their reportage and engage authorities by asking the right and hard questions if their analytical skills have been developed to understand the critical role blockchain is playing and why projects of blockchain should be given the liberty to implement. AJEOT is needed to train journalists in Africa to drive the creation of the legal environment for blockchain projects to thrive. The proposal justified the budget with simplified components including the $7K budget to be used as a flight grant to support participating journalists traveling from outside Ghana as incentives. We don't see why we should be rated low having provided the information.

f6_assessments.q0: The role of the press is vital to creating and sustaining free trade and wealth creation for prosperity. The function of a journalist is to cover major events and minor events. The knowledge of journalists in Africa about blockchain technology and its impact on economic and social development is very limited. Your proposal used the African Journalists Economic Opportunity Training (AJEOT) program to develop the analytical skills and capacities of journalists to participate in and influence the development and apply blockchain policy. I see this as a very potential proposal to enhance the work of journalists in Africa to lead blockchain conversations for policy and legislative development that will enable blockchain innovators, property owners willing to join the Cardano ecosystem. The proposal introduced some risks which are costs for journalists to travel from different countries and attend training in Ghana. The solution to overcome the risk is not specific you need to clarify where does the soft subsidy to support journalists come from?

The implementation of the training program should be designed in the direction of two-way interaction so that journalists can access new knowledge in an active and active way, making it easier for journalists to turn it into their own knowledge to Share and spread to the community. f6_assessments.q0: Building competent journalists in sub-Saharan Africa is an issue in this regard as it impacts policy debate and sets the right tone for blockchain discourse. The author offers a solution to this problem by using the Economic Opportunity Training for African Journalists to develop the analytical skills and competencies of journalists that impact the development and apply blockchain policy. This very idea can perfectly solve this challenge. This proposal can scale up the challenge to address future problems. The main risk that could affect the proposal is the cost for journalists to travel from different countries and attend training in Ghana. They don't have a lot of money for these trips. Their workaround is to provide a soft grant that can assist journalists with travel expenses. If this proposal is funded, I think this project will be successful.
f6_assessments.q1: This project is clearly timed AJEOT is a three-day residency and intensive training course for journalists. This project is estimated by the author to be implemented within 8 weeks. The author is divided into 3 phases, namely: phase 1 is planned from week 1 to week 2, phase 2 is implemented from week 3 to week 7 and phase 3 is implemented from week 3. 7 to 8. This proposal has clearly defined timelines, the implementation time is reasonable with the results of the work, the goals are detailed by the author for each job to be done. The solution of this proposal would be to build the capacity of journalists to understand blockchain, its workings and the function of cryptocurrencies in order to meaningfully participate and create a voice on inclusivity in the media. policy discourse, creating an environment for blockchain innovators to operate freely. Those who pass the training will understand how blockchain technology provides quality decentralization and more democratization in every aspect of our society. The success of the project is the impact of training on journalists and the number of initiatives they take that contribute to making the world freer and building blockchain readiness and a digital future. This is a good project if funded I think this project will be successful.
